WRITING.TEXT: I have a Generalized Anxiety Disorder (or so the free public health doctor told me) and I find when I consume cannabis it helps me think calmy, rationally, and prevents the panic attacks/shakes I get from being so anxious all the time.

Worked at McD's for about three weeks. The manager tried to tell me if the drawer came up short then it would come out of my check. I laughed and told them to their face how super illegal that was and I'd like to see them try.
I was never short thankfully but I left soon afterwards. I suck at handling fuckery.

In how many books do you honestly have male protagonist who actively rapes women? Out of all those books how many depict it as a good thing?
It's like no one looking at this chart cares about the context of these words only their association.

Our culture
Our culture doesn't paint anything, individuals do.
Sure there are plenty of depictions of violence towards women but there are tons of violence towards men as well. Grand landscapes that show men brutally dying on the battlefields waging pointless wars against equally dumb founded enemies.
But you and I both know that we don't ALWAYS paints women that way.
I went to an art gallery several months ago and out of all the pieces there only one depicted a woman in any sort of peril. A lot of them were pictures of beautiful and regal women just sitting there. Hardly in any sort of peril.
I think you're looking for sexism where it doesn't exist.
Is there is trope that isn't lazy that features the man as the perp and the woman as the victim?
Attempted suicide. She didn't actually kill herself.

Dragonland - Astronomy
This is beautiful metal.

Does this really tell us anything though?
Words associated with gender from the synopsis of just over 100k books from unspecified times ago.
Who cares if "He murders" or "she kisses" why are they doing these things and to whom? What is the context behind these stories?
This is just data bait setting people up to think something sexist is going on.

So does a female being the victim and the male being a hero automatically make something a lazy trope?
It would seem to me you're dismissing the concept before it's even introduced.
I may be going out on a limb here and I'm not saying you think this but it seems this chart is almost starting some kind of discussion revolving around gender and the roles these play in the literary world but is it so bad to suggest we hold our opinions until we read what the author writes?
If an author writes a classic hero saving the damsel in distress story do we dismiss it because it's follow a classic trope or would it simply be more prudent to read the story and judge it based on it's technical prowess, story, and message?
I think it's odd that people assume that because a girl needs saving it makes her weak...not saying you said that and it may be a strawman but it would seem to be the general idea.
I find data like this to be unhelpful because it only shows us words in relation to the gender they were found by in the synopsis of the book's story. No context or reason for these words.
I have nothing to gain from seeing the world "man" and "murder" next to each other just like "woman" and "kiss" mean nothing to me either. Who is he murdering? Who is she kissing? Why is she kissing them? Why is he murdering them?
The books aren't about our psyches they are about the story contained within and if you, yes I'm talking to you now /u/Reasonably_Lucid, can't see that you need to re-evaluate why you're reading a book in the first place. I certainly don't read books to power my psyche...do you?
In my personal opinion, your comment sounds very akin to a comment someone who was all about social justice would make.
Diablo III is being held back by lack of gameplay. The game is in it's Twilight Years already in my opinion. I'm pretty much waiting for Diablo 4 at this point before I return to the franchise.

I finally got to play Blood Dragon and I am 50/50 on it.
The game is really self aware and I like it for that reason but the whole experience is so disjointed and pointless sometimes. The unlocks cost so much money and once you get the gatling gun Blood Dragons are no longer the crazy threat they used to be.
I think most people play it and like the retro references so assume it's good but really it's super short and really limited in it's game play.
It can be beat in less than a few hours and 100% in less than ten. Not that good of a game imo.

As a huge fan of the Saints Row series I have to disagree with both you and /u/Taz666.
Saints Row 3 onward were just an outright mockery of what the Saints universe had become.
They went from having a very serious albeit funny and unusual theme to just out right bonkers shit.
It was the video game equivalent of a kid learning something makes you laugh then driving that shit into the ground until it's not funny anymore.
Shit, the main reason Gat out of Hell even exists is because one of the endings resets the Saints Universe to make room for the next game they are making which will have the Saints in some capacity but it's a different world where the Saints never happened.
Even the creators knew they took it too far and wrote in an ending that would allow them to back out from their own bullshit.
Saints Row and Saints Row 2 are golden examples of open world video games from the 2000's.
Saints Row 3, IV, and Gat out of Hell were a mockery of the former games. Hell they were even easier to beat and less technically sound.
Saints Row IV is literally a repainted Saints Row 3. They used the same fucking city for Christ sake.
At least in the transition from Saints Row to Saints Row 2 they used the same city but made it different enough to qualify as a new map.

SJW is cringey?
It's an acronym for Social Justice Warrior is a term, whether given or taken, that is used as a stand in for those who fight excessively for social justice when none is to be had.
What's cringey is the out right childish behavior displayed by groups emblazoned with the SJW moniker. The lies tons of college kids are believing pushed onto them by social justice teachers is sickening, it's like a hateful religion but without a god.
There are people who seriously get on the news and say: "We just need less white people." And yet this people claim they are the paragons of social justice and righteousness. Bull. Shit.

Well I've never thought of us melding with the machines but that is also a possibility. Why give a machine a better brain than us when we could give it to ourselves?
That or my hypothesis a self taught machine, were it more advanced than a human, would understand concepts like mercy and empathy. These are human traits that are shown to develop with education so surely a machine would develop them too assuming it has a brain more complex than our own.

What no one seems to understand is why would the AI go hostile in the first place?
If a machine is capable of thinking as we do, self taught and learning, which is everyone fear, what makes it incapable of understanding concepts like empathy?
Everyone seems to think a self taught machine would lack human qualities and we be absurdly evil in the pursuit of it's mission.
